H0.text: A lightweight core surrounded by neutral particles is the best description of the structure of an atom.

H1.text: A massive core surrounded by negatively-charged particles best describes the structure of an atom.

H2.text: A network of interacting positive and negative particles best describes the structure of an atom.

H3.text: Overlapping layers of neutral, positive, and negative particles best describe the structure of an atom.

A4.text: Almost all of the mass of an atom is located in the nucleus.

A5.text: An atom is composed of a positively charged nucleus, with a cloud of negatively charged electrons surrounding it, bound together by electrostatic force.

A6.text: The electron (e−, or β− in nuclear reactions) is a subatomic particle whose electric charge is negative one elementary charge.

A7.text: The chemical bond between atoms occurs as a result of electromagnetic interactions, as described by the laws of quantum mechanics.
